Jackson, GA 30233

citations.narrative:
Sharp points within two outdoor enclosures were noted as follows:
• The top wire of the enclosure fence for four cows, near their water receptacle, was broken and bent inwards
approximately 6 inches causing a sharp point of wire, approximately 2-3 inches long, to point into the enclosure at
approximately 3 ½ to 4 feet from the ground.
• A large wooden furniture structure located within the primary enclosure of the goats has deteriorated such that the top
had a portion of wood missing and multiple sharp ends of metal nails remaining that pointed up and out of its top, varying
in height from approximately 2 to 3 inches.
The areas identified above could cause harm to the animals by allowing injury from the exposed sharp points. The
outdoor housing facilities must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury or
escape.
Corrected at the time of inspection and to stay corrected from this date, January 8, 2026, forward.

The following deficiencies were identified with the facility’s perimeter fence:
• To the left of a closed access gate that leads to walking trails for the public, located by the red fox’s outdoor enclosure,
an approximately 6-inch gap was found between the perimeter fence and the gate that spanned vertically from the ground
up, for the full height of the 8 foot high fence, that could allow animals to pass through it.
• There was a significant gap below the perimeter fence at another closed gate, located to the left of the property where a
rocked parking lot for the public is provided. The gap ranges from 5 to 6 inches in height for a length of about 12 feet
which doesn't adequately prevent other animals from passing under it.
• The wire mesh of the perimeter fence to the left of the gate at the public gravel parking lot was pushed down, creating a
large gap of approximately 2 feet between the wire mesh and the added single strand of top wire, due to the amount of
leaning and loose wire mesh spanning between the fence posts. The fence height was approximately 6 feet in height for
about 10 feet in fence length in two areas to the left of the gate. The wire mesh being pushed in and/or down is causing
loose wire fencing in this section, and therefore, not an effective barrier nor tall enough for dangerous species (bears).
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals (bears) and 6-foot-high fencing for non-dangerous animals (opossum,
beaver, foxes, groundhogs, bobcats, coyotes, and racoons). Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the
primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors.
Correct by: April 1, 2026.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Sharp points within two outdoor enclosures were noted as follows: 
• The top wire of the enclosure fence for four cows, near their water receptacle, was broken and bent inwards 
approximately 6 inches causing a sharp point of wire, approximately 2-3 inches long, to point into the enclosure at 
approximately 3 ½ to 4 feet from the ground.  
• A large wooden furniture structure located within the primary enclosure of the goats has deteriorated such that the top 
had a portion of wood missing and multiple sharp ends of metal nails remaining that pointed up and out of its top, varying 
in height from approximately 2 to 3 inches. 
The areas identified above could cause harm to the animals by allowing injury from the exposed sharp points. The 
outdoor housing facilities must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury or 
escape. 
Corrected at the time of inspection and to stay corrected from this date, January 8, 2026, forward. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The following deficiencies were identified with the facility’s perimeter fence:  
• To the left of a closed access gate that leads to walking trails for the public, located by the red fox’s outdoor enclosure, 
an approximately 6-inch gap was found between the perimeter fence and the gate that spanned vertically from the ground 
up, for the full height of the 8 foot high fence, that could allow animals to pass through it. 
• There was a significant gap below the perimeter fence at another closed gate, located to the left of the property where a 
rocked parking lot for the public is provided. The gap ranges from 5 to 6 inches in height for a length of about 12 feet 
which doesn't adequately prevent other animals from passing under it.  
• The wire mesh of the perimeter fence to the left of the gate at the public gravel parking lot was pushed down, creating a 
large gap of approximately 2 feet between the wire mesh and the added single strand of top wire, due to the amount of 
leaning and loose wire mesh spanning between the fence posts. The fence height was approximately 6 feet in height for 
about 10 feet in fence length in two areas to the left of the gate. The wire mesh being pushed in and/or down is causing 
loose wire fencing in this section, and therefore, not an effective barrier nor tall enough for dangerous species (bears).  
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an 
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier

to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals (bears) and 6-foot-high fencing for non-dangerous animals (opossum, 
beaver, foxes, groundhogs, bobcats, coyotes, and racoons). Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the 
primary enclosure for animals housed outdoors. 
Correct by: April 1, 2026. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
